prompt_init: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
initial_story: What the he'll is going on that we are struggling with these facilities that take care of the mentally challenged or health care for Alzheimer's patients that have other medical issues?  St. Mary's in Grand Junction just discharged a friend who broke a hip and has Alzheimer's without rehab for the hip and no place with beds open for Alzheimer's!  Ludicrous!  The "authorities" closed the facility to accommodate "challenged " residents here last year and re-located them to Denver.  Again, ridiculous!  Our health care system is without compassion and based on the bottom line!  The worst part is drug addicts, emergency room mangers of all sorts can get care but we treat those who have health issues as seniors like shit! Sad state of affairs!  Shame on healthcare and those who do not fight for dignity in end of life care!  Shameful!  Politicians should be shamed for not supporting a bill that cares for these people!
stories: What the heck is going on with the facilities that take care of the mentally challenged and Alzheimer's patients with other medical issues? St. Mary's in Grand Junction just discharged a friend who broke a hip and has Alzheimer's without rehab for the hip and no place with beds open for Alzheimer's! Ridiculous! The "authorities" closed the facility to accommodate "challenged " residents here last year and re-located them to Denver. Again, ridiculous! Our healthcare system is without compassion and based on the bottom line! The worst part is drug addicts, emergency room managers of all sorts can get care but we treat those who have health issues as seniors like shit! Sad state of affairs! Shame on healthcare and those who do not fight for dignity in end of life care! Shameful! Politicians should be shamed for not supporting a bill that cares for these people!

There is a serious issue with the facilities that provide care for the mentally challenged and Alzheimer's patients with other medical issues. For instance, St. Mary's in Grand Junction recently discharged a friend who broke a hip and has Alzheimer's, but did not provide any rehabilitation for the hip or a place with available beds for Alzheimer's patients. This is unacceptable! The "authorities" closed the facility last year to make room for "challenged" residents, who were then relocated to Denver. This is also unacceptable! Our healthcare system lacks compassion and prioritizes profits over people. The worst part is that drug addicts and emergency room "managers" can receive care, while seniors with health issues are treated like garbage. This is a sad state of affairs. Shame on the healthcare system and those who do not fight for dignity in end-of-life care. Shameful! Politicians should be ashamed for not supporting a bill that provides care for these people!

This is a problem that needs to be addressed. For example, a friend of mine broke their hip and was diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease, but they were released from St. Mary's in Grand Junction without receiving the rehabilitation they needed for their hip injury and without being placed in a facility that could meet their needs. This lack of care is a serious issue. Last year, the facility closed to make room for "challenged" residents, who were relocated to Denver. This is also a problem. The healthcare system prioritizes profits over the well-being of people and lacks compassion. Drug addicts and emergency room "managers" receive care, while elderly people with health problems are treated like garbage. This is a tragic situation. It is a shame that the healthcare system and those who do not advocate for dignity in end-of-life care are not doing more. Politicians should be ashamed that they did not support a bill that would provide care for these people.
